Right I thought the 'best' order could be based on how
many times users click 'Next Page'. So that fitness is
inversly proportional to the number of times they
click 'Next Page'.
However if it is worth doing I wasn't sure if a Search
Continer would have the brain and then it would
contain a list of search results or if each search
result would have a brain?

Thanks so much,
Rog


--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:

> Roger Smith wrote:
> 
> >Yeah I barely understand my own requirements!
> >Anyway, I will give it a try, it might help me to
> >explain it better anyway.
> >
> >So currently I have a system that searches through
> a
> >database using SqlSever FullText Indexing.  This
> >basically prevents me from having to write the LIKE
> >statements etc....
> >Well I was thinking about rathing than using that
> >coming up with a set of inputs such as Page UpTime,
> >Num Clicks, etc.. and using those inputs into the
> >Neural Network and using Ga to evolve the weights. 
> >Well I have looked at the smartsweepers example on
> >ai-junkie and Matt has done a gerat job, but I am
> not
> >sure how I could apply it to my solution. For
> instance
> >inthe smartsweepers problem he had a controller
> which
> >iterataed through the sweepers and each sweeper had
> a
> >brain independent of the other sweepers. For my
> >problem would I have a SearchSweeper with its own
> >brain and then it would get a list of results from
> the
> >database(perhaps FullText INdexing still) and then
> >rank them on the basis of the weights of the inputs
> or
> >should each search result have its own brain and
> >determine its own ranking?
> >Does that help, not sure if it does.
> >Thanks,
> >Rog
> >  
> >
> Hi Roger, I don't know anything about smartsweepers
> I'm afraid but I 
> think I'm starting to get the picture. You want to
> rank the search 
> results from an SQL server query, so that instead of
> having to deal with 
> g the raw, un-ranked search results from SQL you
> want to pass each 
> result, in turn, through a network and for the
> network to output a 
> ranking,  or some variation on this scheme that
> gives you a ranked list 
> of search results, right?
> 
> I'm not sure what benefit such a  scheme would
> provide over simple 
> weighting of the various factors, such as page-up
> time, and other 
> factors such as the proximity of the various
> keywords and the frequency 
> they occur on a page. Google of course also factors
> in how many links 
> point to a page from elsewhere on the web - but my
> guess would be that 
> they take all of these factors, give some more
> weight than others, total 
> them all up and sort them so that the highest
> scoring pages occurs first 
> in the list.  Now, perhaps a Neural Net could apply
> a more intelligent 
> analysis of the various factors, but then there is
> the problem of 
> determining the 'best' order that the search results
> could be in so that 
> you can train a network to achieve that 'best'
> order.
> 
> Colin.
>
